2022-02-18 Riddler Classic
==========================
Another case of the binomial distribution.

When there are n coins, the chance of not eventually getting the "luckiest"
coin is
```
  P(n) = 1/2ⁿ + ∑₁ⁿ⁻¹P(k)n!/(k!(n-k)!2ⁿ) + P(n)/2ⁿ
  P(1) = 0

  P(n) = (1 + ∑₁ⁿ⁻¹P(k)n!/(k!(n-k)!))/(2ⁿ-1)
```
and the chance of eventually getting the "luckiest" coin is 1-P(n).

Using [code](20220218.hs), the first few are
```
  1-P(2) = 2/3
  1-P(3) = 5/7
  1-P(4) = 76/105
  1-P(5) = 157/217
  1-P(6) = 470/651, or about 0.72197

  1-P(20) = 2696377138892109703091196777892892/3738221859966377029027349751709185,
  or about 0.72130

  1-P(50) = ,
  or about 0.72135

  1-P(100) = ,
  or about 0.72135

  1-P(150) = ,
  or about 0.72134

  1-P(200) = ,
  or about 0.72135

  1-P(250) = ,
  or about 0.72135
```

So 1-P(n) appears to converge to about 72.135% for large n.
